name: Quercetin
summary: Quercetin is a plant flavonoid with antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective properties, studied for immune, cardiovascular, and potential mental health benefits.
description: Quercetin is a bioflavonoid naturally found in fruits, vegetables, tea, and red wine. It acts as a potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory compound, modulating cellular signaling pathways, histamine release, and cytokine activity. Quercetin has been studied for its potential in supporting immune resilience, reducing allergy symptoms, improving cardiovascular health, and providing neuroprotective effects. In mental health, quercetin may influence oxidative stress, neuroinflammation, and mitochondrial function, though psychiatric evidence remains preliminary.

metadata.natural_source: Onions, apples, berries, green tea, red wine, capers
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

contraindications: Kidney disease (high doses may increase risk of nephrotoxicity)
monitoring_required: Renal function in high-dose or prolonged use

items: Reduces allergy symptoms via mast cell stabilization
May reduce oxidative stress and inflammation

sections.text: Quercetin exerts antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects by scavenging free radicals, inhibiting lipid peroxidation, and modulating signaling pathways such as NF-κB. It stabilizes mast cells to reduce histamine release, influences cytokine expression, and promotes mitochondrial function. Neuroprotective effects may stem from reduced oxidative stress and improved blood–brain barrier integrity.

adult.note: Often combined with vitamin C or bromelain to enhance absorption.

sections.text: Allergy and immune effects may be noticed within weeks; cardiovascular and neuroprotective effects require longer-term use.

serious: Kidney toxicity at very high doses (rare)

other: High doses may increase risk of kidney stress.
Bioavailability is low; specialized formulations (e.g., phytosome) improve absorption.

sections.pregnancy: Insufficient safety data; avoid unless prescribed
sections.lactation: Not recommended due to lack of safety data
sections.pediatrics: Not well studied; avoid supplementation outside clinical supervision
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; monitor renal function with prolonged use

sections.text: No tapering required; effects diminish gradually after discontinuation.

items: Frequently combined with bromelain for enhanced anti-inflammatory effects.
Research in psychiatric conditions is preliminary, with some interest in oxidative stress and inflammation pathways.
Quercetin absorption varies significantly depending on formulation.
